Posts.Content: Originally Posted by oshguy ... And lastly, these wet pads and Depends briefs are causing some mild "diaper rash." I wash with soap and water every time I change pads/briefs and apply a skin cream with aloe, which helps, but wondered if anyone has found anything better. But for some reason occasional diaper rash has plagued me. Be patient.

I use Tricare insurance.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Slide Show

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rwewpar4 ... I discussed this with my wife and she wasn’t certain that she was comfortable with the idea of artificially achieving an erection. She said that she may need to talk to a councilor. First, congratulations on getting diagnosed in time, and your successful surgery. Next, from how I read your post, your wife recognizes that she has an issue, and that she needs therapy. Which is actually a big step. My wife had a back injury a couple years after we were married. As a side effect she began menopause at 25 and began feeling pain during intercourse. Her body could no longer lubricate, and she quickly lost interest in sex. Most of our 35 years of marriage has been celibate. Now that I am post-surgery, I like all men, am concerned if I can have an erection. Like you in your position, my wife does not care. So here we are. I understand frustration brother. I have found that the Tri-mix injections work really well. If you do not like the vacuum pump, you can always try the injections.

Posts.Title: Frustrated

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by chasisme ... Urologist was "puzzled" that all of the samples had some degree of cancer and yet my psa is 6.61. Is there an explanation for that. There are no hard / fast rules. A low PSA does not guarantee a low Gleason. A high PSA does not guarantee a high Gleason. There are general trends, but no solid rules. ... He was also worried because one of the samples is close to a "nerve" and found an urgency to get moving. I agree, it is moving toward the nerve-bundle. The nerve-bundle sheath is an avenue through which the cancer can spread. If it reaches that, then it will spread to your lymphs and bones. There is need for urgency. My surgeon said that he had decided to spare-the-nerve in these cases, too many times, and too many of them spread anyway. My surgeon insisted on taking the nerve, to guarantee that it did not spread. Because my cancer was so close to the nerve-bundle. Time is not in your favor. Surgery can only work, so long as the cancer remains in one organ. It sounds like your cancer is attempting to leave your prostate. The choice is yours. I wish you the best.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by chasisme ... Urologist was "puzzled" that all of the samples had some degree of cancer and yet my psa is 6.61. Is there an explanation for that. There are no hard / fast rules. A low PSA does not guarantee a low Gleason. A high PSA does not guarantee a high Gleason. There are general trends, but no solid rules. ... He was also worried because one of the samples is close to a "nerve" and found an urgency to get moving. I agree, it is moving toward the nerve-bundle. The nerve-bundle sheath is an avenue through which the cancer can spread. If it reaches that, then it will spread to your lymphs and bones. There is need for urgency. My surgeon said that he had decided to spare-the-nerve in these cases, too many times, and too many of them spread anyway. My surgeon insisted on taking the nerve, to guarantee that it did not spread. Because my cancer was so close to the nerve-bundle. Time is not in your favor. Surgery can only work, so long as the cancer remains in one organ. It sounds like your cancer is attempting to leave your prostate. The choice is yours. I wish you the best.

Along with sneezing or coughing. The worst is when farting. After I urinate there was a mild pain, in the first 3 weeks. I must wear a diaper when I sleep. Posts.Content: When I had mine done, both scans were scheduled for the same day. I asked for both to be burned onto CDs and I took them home with me. I enjoyed going over the scans at home, at my leisure. There is a lot of media available online showing exactly what you are looking for in those scans. When I later sat with my Urologist. He read the lab notes and then we and I both went over the scans. Because I had looked at them previously, I had intelligent questions to ask of him. I saw things that I pointed out to him, and I learned even more. Do it and have fun

Posts.Content: Get other opinions. The longer you wait, before acting, we are assuming that your cancer will be growing. Maybe it will grow slowly, maybe it will decide to grow fast. As it grows, the consequences of each treatment will change. IMHO, right now you know absolutely that it has not left the prostate. The worst thing that can happen, is it could spread, right now you are in a window where it has not spread. Have it removed.

Posts.Title: Biopsy Positive

Posts.Content: I am an organic farmer. In a field of 40 different types of cancers, there are a few types of cancer strongly linked to diet. The type of cancer with the strongest known link is colon cancer, the negative links for colon cancer are red meats and nitrates. For prostate cancer the known positive links are lycopene and pomegranate. But even a diet rich in these does not guarantee anything. Cumin and turmeric are both associated with one of the cancers, but I do not recall which one. There are many different types of cancer. What triggers one, is different from what triggers another. Nothing totally prevents any of them. Prevention is a matter of reducing risk. But say if you have a 90% chance of getting prostate cancer, reducing that risk to only 85% is something, but it is not a huge preventative. Here I am. Into organics, mid-50s, outdoors and active lifestyle, I eat all the right things. I have been attending an annual workshop presented locally by a Oncologist on the most recent research into dietary links to cancers. He has a wonderful presentation, there have been thousands of studies done. He is the only person I am aware of trying to compile the data, and present it in a workshop. I have been adjusting my diet according to the latest research. My PCP was shocked that I wanted a PSA test done with my last check-up. Initially she refused to even test me. I had to talk her into it. In her mind, I fit the image of a man who would never have prostate cancer. It was a total surprise that I had a PSA of 22 and gleason 9.

Posts.Title: Food and Prostate

Posts.Content: In all cases, it is really up to the discretion of the surgeon during the operation. His training, his experience, his ability to recognize if the nerves can be safely spared, or not. Before the surgery, he can look at the tests, and he can make a general guess as to what will happen during the surgery. But it is a guess. Before my operation, my surgeon told me that given my test results, my nerves needed to go. Previously in his career he had spared the nerves, in cases like mine, and in those cases, the cancer spread. The more you focus on nerve-sparing, the more likely that the cancer will not all be removed. In my case, he seemed pretty sure that if he spared the nerves, I would still have cancer. He told us all of this, before my surgery date. I would hope that your cancer has not spread to such an extent, and that your nerves can be spared.

Posts.Title: My PSA is 'undetectable' :)

Posts.Content: Last week I had my first PSA test after surgery, and yesterday we met with the urologist to get the test results. 'Undetectable' Woo Hoo I am to be re-tested every 3 months, for the next year. After that, we can shift to annual re-testing. He asked me about leakage. I have not needed a diaper for 2 months now, and I have not used any pad for about a month. I still get a small bit of leakage when I am tired, or when I have had a few drinks. But I do not leak when I am sleeping. He said that I am well above par for this, as many men will be fighting leakage for up to a year after surgery. During the surgery he also clipped the artery that leads to my testicles to remove a varicocele, that he been bothering me since I was a teenager. So the urologist wanted to inspect how much the varicocele had deflated, and if it was bothering me any more. I am very happy with that also, as the varicocele seems to be completely gone. I asked him about viagra. He said that he could give me viagra, but it will not work on me. Because he removed the nerve bundle, the mechanism of viagra will not function for me. Instead what I will need to do is the injections. He ordered the script for me, and said I will need an appointment for them to instruct me on where exactly to inject myself.

Posts.Title: Trimix vs MUSE??

Posts.Content: Hello; My prostatectomy was on the 14th, on the 22nd my catheter was removed. on the 26th I noticed that I was passing some blood in my urine. I am not in any pain. In accordance with my post-op documents, I went to an ER. For their urine sample, there was obvious blood in the sample. After a few hours, I was given Cipro, told that this is normal, and I was sent home. They contacted my urologist, and followed his advice. Somehow I am not comforted with this development. When I was released from the hospital post-surgery, I had no blood in my urine. So I was not expecting to see any now. How normal is this?

Posts.Title: One more day and the cathater comes out. I do have a concern though

Posts.Content: I am glad that I had PSA tests done. If I had not had PSA tests done, I would likely be the example of the guy who was not detected until it was too late. My wife is on a couple other forums. As it turns out, there she speaks with a nurse from Canada and a MD from Auz. Both of them, had previously told her that in their regions PSA are not used like this. Both of them recommended to her, for me 'not' to have the biopsy. "... PSA is too unreliable, the chances of it being an aggressive cancer are minimal, etc". Since my surgery, both of those posters, have came back and apologized to my wife for their bad advice. This is a problem of 'Herd Management'. If you look at the entire herd, when you see a disease spreading, you give out vaxx. Even when you know at the outset, that your vaxx will kill and maim a small percentage. It is better for the herd, to stop the spread of the disease, and ignore those you have killed or maimed. I had a friend who was a lab-tech who spent his career making the polio vaxx. As an elderly man, his biggest regret was the thousands of children that his work had maimed. They never went on to perfect a 'cure' that lacked the known side effects [1 out of 1,000 will be maimed in this manner, so many will have that reaction, etc]. If healthcare is done from a viewpoint of herd management, then you accept the anticipated losses. Radiation is done in this manner. You do harm, on purpose, in the hope that most of the herd will be okay. Look at Chinese medicine, or on the other hand Ayurvedic medicine. Both systems have been around for thousands of years. Both have had to treat these same diseases. Neither system intentionally harms you, with the intent that maybe you will be among the lucky to survive the treatment.

PSA is too unreliable, the chances of it being an aggressive cancer are minimal, etc". Since my surgery, both of those posters, have came back and apologized to my wife for their bad advice. This is a problem of 'Herd Management'. If you look at the entire herd, when you see a disease spreading, you give out vaxx. Even when you know at the outset, that your vaxx will kill and maim a small percentage. It is better for the herd, to stop the spread of the disease, and ignore those you have killed or maimed. I had a friend who was a lab-tech who spent his career making the polio vaxx. As an elderly man, his biggest regret was the thousands of children that his work had maimed. They never went on to perfect a 'cure' that lacked the known side effects [1 out of 1,000 will be maimed in this manner, so many will have that reaction, etc]. If healthcare is done from a viewpoint of herd management, then you accept the anticipated losses. Radiation is done in this manner. You do harm, on purpose, in the hope that most of the herd will be okay. Look at Chinese medicine, or on the other hand Ayurvedic medicine. Both systems have been around for thousands of years. Both have had to treat these same diseases. Neither system intentionally harms you, with the intent that maybe you will be among the lucky to survive the treatment.

Posts.Title: Post Surgery Recovery

Posts.Content: I have noticed that my penis does seem to be much smaller. However given that the erectile tissue had not been stretched out for 3 months, it would make sense. I think, that normally a little daily wood, generally keeps your penis working and stretching. 3 months post-surgery I tried the Tri-mix injections. I do think that I fully 'recovered' all of my previous length. I have only used the Tri-mix three times: The first time stretching was painful, both during and for a day afterwards. The second time was better, it was less painful during, and only minor soreness after. The third time the erection lasted over 5 hours, after the second hour it got painful, and it was still sore 2 days later.

Not due to the injection, but the actual erection was painful. 10 years ago, I tried a cheap vacuum pump. I was never able to get a good seal on it. Now that I am recovering from PC I have not re-tried a pump.

Posts.Title: The Prostate has left the building.

Posts.Content: I went in for surgery one morning. I woke-up that night in hospital and I was not in any pain [obviously I had IV meds going]. The next afternoon I was sent home. At that time, I was taking acetaminophen 500mg and oxy 5mg. I had a catheter/bag for a week, then I got it removed. I wore a diaper all day/night for about a week. Then the diaper only when I was in bed for the next 2 weeks. Before going in for surgery, I was taking Naproxen Sodium [Aleve] everyday for mild back pain and to keep my Bursitisis under control. [I am a farmer, I carry sacks of feed / etc around every day] My Urologist wanted me to shift to acetaminophen during my recovery, as it would not interfere with my recovery. When I was sent home, I was given oxy at 5mg for the first week. I only took it 2 days though and did not need it any further. Now 2 months after surgery, I am going back to Naproxen Sodium. Maybe it is because I take a NSAID every day anyway, but I have not had much pain from the site of PC surgery. I also had a varicocelectomy done at the same time. Due to that surgery, my scrotum has been very tender, and it has only faded in the last 2 weeks.

Posts.Content: My surgeon did not 'spare the nerves'. Later from the tissue analysis it turned out that he was right to remove the nerves. What that means is I can not achieve an erection without help. I have injections that do it, or I opt for the implants. I got full bladder control within 8 weeks. Orgasms are weird for me. No muscle spasm, no fluid, it is purely in my brain now.

Posts.Title: Question

Posts.Content: I am new to using Trimix. My pharmacy directed me to put one in the frig for use, and to keep the second frozen until I needed it. They told me that when it is frozen it lasts over a year, when it is held in a frig it only lasts a month. They shipped 2 vials of Trimix to me frozen, via UPS. I saw my urologist 2 days ago, to instruct me on how to do the injections. He also said that it would keep long term frozen, and to only thaw the vial I was using.

A few years ago, this growth of veins had became tender, but the urologist did not want to remove them. Now since I was going into surgery anyway, I convinced this surgeon to do both procedures. Two weeks later, and my stuff is still sore.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by azgreywolf Jebstart, I was left with one nerve, badly damaged. 150mg of Viagra gave a little size, but still too droopy to even try to use. Trimix only got me a semi, again not adequate for penetration. A vacuum pump with 3 rings got me fully up, but much of the blood pushed back out anyway on insertion and I'd be in but floppy. I've had one orgasm via intercourse in 3.5 years. The implant is my last great hope. If you're only 10 months out and getting a semi, give it some time. I've heard surgeons won't do an implant till 24 months post-op at the earliest. I am curious, one damaged nerve and a vacuum pump can get you up, but the blood drains away as soon as the pump is removed. Is that because of the damaged nerve? Anyone? What if the nerve had been removed entirely? Anyone?
